title: Streaming Recommender
summary:
# Summary: Streaming Recommender Systems

This academic paper addresses the challenge of building recommender systems that can handle continuously arriving data streams in real-time. The authors propose a novel framework called **sRec** that provides explicit continuous-time random process models for the creation of users and items, and for the evolution of their interests.

## Problem and Challenges

Real-world recommender systems like eBay and Netflix generate massive amounts of data at unprecedented rates—over 10 million transactions per day for eBay. This data is temporally ordered, continuous, high-velocity, and time-varying, creating a streaming nature that traditional recommender systems cannot handle. The authors identify three key challenges:

1. **Real-time updating**: The system must update and respond instantaneously to capture users' instant intentions
2. **Unknown size**: New users and fresh items arrive continuously, making the number of users and recommendation list sizes unpredictable
3. **Concept shift**: Data stream evolution causes user preferences to drift over time, requiring the system to adapt accordingly

## The sRec Framework

The proposed framework models the streaming setting by assuming continuously time-varying, partially known user-item relationships. Ratings are modeled using an ordered probit model, where each rating is a discretization of a hidden variable representing user-item "likeness." This hidden variable is modeled as the dot product of user and item hidden topic vectors plus Gaussian noise.

For temporal dynamics, the framework uses Brownian motion to model how user and item topic vectors evolve over time. New users are initialized based on the average posterior expectations of existing users, while the very first users receive a standard Gaussian prior. The same approach applies to item factors.

## Inference Methodology

The paper proposes a **recursive meanfield approximation** for computationally efficient instantaneous on-line inference. This method allows the system to maintain posterior distributions by tracking only their first and second moments at the most recent event time. Updates occur only when events happen (new user, new item, or new rating), making the system highly efficient.

For offline parameter estimation, a variational EM algorithm learns the noise variance parameters (σ²_E for ratings, σ²_U for user evolution, σ²_V for item evolution) from historical data.

## Experimental Results

The authors evaluate sRec on three real-world datasets: MovieLens Latest Small, MovieLens-10M, and Netflix. The proposed method significantly outperforms all baseline algorithms including PMF, MDCR, GPFM, and Time-SVD++ across all three datasets. The paper notes that Time-SVD++ performed second best because it models temporal information more suitably under streaming settings, but its inflexibility to temporal granularity limits its ability to capture volatile changes.

A particularly interesting finding emerges from the learned parameters: the "half-time" for user interests is approximately 3.12 years, while item topics change much more slowly with a half-time of 13.06 years. This quantitatively confirms the intuition that user tastes evolve significantly faster than item characteristics, explaining why many existing recommender systems only model user dynamics while treating item topics as fixed.

The qualitative analysis demonstrates that sRec can effectively track user interest evolution over time, showing how individual users' preferences for specific movies shift continuously—for example, one user's initial strong interest in "The Silence of the Lambs" gradually decreases while their preference for "Ace Ventura" increases over time.
